Informal proof of det(M1M2) = det(M1)det(M2) (not in one sentence though):

Recall that the determinant is just a scalar. The transformation composition M1M2 is the total effect of applying M2 first (scales the space by det(M2)) then M1 (scales the space by det(M1)). By taking the product det(M1)det(M2) (scalar multiplication is commutative), we then get the total scaling effect of M1M2 on the space, given by det(M1M2).

Imagine this as just transforming (by consequence, scaling) a number line using two 1x1 matrices A and B in whatever order. We transform the unit line by A, so the transformed length of the unit line is now det(A), then we apply B, so the length of the unit line is now det(A)det(B) (in short, 1 * det(A) * det(B)). You can then extend this thought to higher dimensions.

7:33 You can also prove this using vectors.
We know the determinant equals the area of the parallelogram between i-hat and j-hat. The area of a parallelogram between two vectors can be calculated as the magnitude of the cross product between those two vectors. But since the cross product is only defined in 3 dimensions, we can think of two-dimensional space as a plane that sits at 0 on the z-axis. That way, we can extrapolate i-hat and j-hat (and thus any other vector in two-dimensional space) into three dimensions by simply putting 0 in the last line. We can now calculate the determinant of a matrix [ a b (new line) c d ] as the magnitude of the cross product of the transformed versions of i-hat [a c 0] and j-hat [b d 0], which ultimately turns out to be the square root of (a*d - c*b)², since both the x-axis and the y-axis of the resulting cross product yield a value of 0 (which kinda makes sense if you think about it, since the cross product of two vectors is defined as another vector being at right angles to both, so if we enter two vectors that both do not move along the z-axis, the resulting vector will move only along the z-axis).

Instead of ad-bc, if you write this as ix*jy - iy*jx, you'll see that this is the square defined by the directions in which i and j were originally long, subtracted by the directions in which i and j were originally short. And that's why is needs to be ab-bc not bc-ad!!

In fact, that's a fine way to describe the determinant of a matrix! It's the area given by the area in the dimensions in which your basis vectors were long, less the area given by the dimensions in which your basis vectors were short. In this definition, a negative area makes sense - if one of the dimensions in which your basis vector was positive turned out negative, you'll have a negative area, since you've inverted that dimension!

Q: Why does the concept of determinant only work for square matrices?
A: (My understanding)
Determinant of a square matrix is defined as the factor by which an area/volume/hypervolume is scaled after performing a transformation.

A square matrix (e.g., 2x2, 3x3) represents a linear transformation that maintains the number of dimensions before and after the transformation. The concept of factor scaling makes sense in this case, because a 2D area remains a 2D area, while a 3D volume remains a 3D volume, and so on.

A non-square matrix (e.g., 2x3, 4x3), on the other hand, is a linear transformation that jumps between dimensions (see Chapter 8, Essence of linear algebra). The concept of factor scaling doesn’t make sense in this case, because it doesn’t make sense to define a scaling factor which accounts for shape changes after transformation, from 2D to 3D for example (as represented by a 3x2 matrix).

P.S. for the determinant of two matrixes multiplied, you can first analyze the determinants of elementary matrixes (notated as E) multiplied by a matrix C, which corresponds to det(EC)=det(E)•det(C).

Then, for det(AB), assume that both A and B are invertible, which implies that the columns are linearly independent and the determinant is non-zero. Because of this, matrix A can be defined as a set of elementary matrices (Ek...E1) that are equivalent to A when multiplied with one another. This goes to the first statement that det(EC)=det(E)•det(C). Do that for each elementary matrix that represent A, then det(AB) = det[(Ek•...•E1)•B]= det(Ek)•...det(E1)•det(B). Combine the elementary matrices again, which says that det(Ek•...•E1)•det(B) = det(A)•det(B).

Now, when at least one matrix is not invertible, then it is linearly dependent. Assuming without any loss of generality that A is non-invertible, then det(A) = 0 and AB will be a linearly dependent matrix, and thus, non-invertible as well. Since AB is linearly dependent, then the det(AB) = 0 = 0•det(B) = det(A)•det(B).

Therefore, det(AB)=det(A)•det(B)

For this, I assumed that it is known that det(EC)=det(E)•det(C) where E is an elementary matrix, and I also assumed the first theorem that det(A) is ≠ 0 iff A is invertible.

Answer to Why Det(M1*M2)=Det(M1)*Det(M2) ?


Considering each matrix as independent LINEAR transformations, each of its determinant gives the area of the re-scaled unit area. Matrix multiplication is sequentially applying both the transformations(Right to Left), so the second transformation is re-scaling of the re-scaled unit matrix during first transformation.

(1:48) <- this concept says;
(Re-scaled area of a transformation) = (Re-scaled unit area after Transformation) * (Current area under consideration).

(Determinant of M1) = (Re-scaled unit area after Transformation M1).
(Determinant of M2) = (Re-scaled unit area after Transformation M2).

In case of M1*M2 ;
For the second transformation(M1), the current area under consideration would be the re-scaled unit area after the first transformation (M2) ;

(Determinant of M1*M2) = (Re-scaled unit area after Transformation M1) * (Re-scaled unit area after Transformation M2).

So, in one line the answer would be:
(Re-scaled area of a transformation) = (Re-scaled unit area after Transformation) * (Current area under consideration).

It definitely makes sense to think of the equation y=mx as a one-dimensional linear transformation, performed by multiplying the "vector" x by the 1x1 matrix (aka scalar) m. The only possible kind of one-dimensional linear transformation simply scales x. The "determinant" of this 1x1 matrix is just the matrix (again, scalar) itself, which of course tells you the signed (direction-encoded) factor by which x is scaled. Thought of as a vector, this factor therefore scales the length of x. So the intuition about determinants not only scales to dimensions higher than 3 (where it represents an orientation-encoded scaling factor of what I'll call n-volumes), but scales down to one dimension, which is not generally considered in linear algebra.

Two remarks that might interest you:

1. There is another meaning of the 2x2 determinant formula, related to the cross product: Think of one column vector as a wind force blowing onto a paddle given by the other column vector. Then this generates a torque proportional to the oriented area spanned by both vectors. Decompose both vectors along x and y, then only components at right angles generate torque: so the total torque is

(x component of L(i)) * (y component of L(j)) - (x component of L(j)) * (y component of L(i)) = ad - bc

The minus sign stems from the opposite orientation of that second contribution.

2. The cofactor expansion for calculating the determinant, as arcane as it may appear, also has geometric interpretation: It amounts to shearing the parallelepiped along the components of one of its spanning vectors, making use of the shear invariance of volume (which is simply Cavalieri's Principle). The paralleleliped is thus sheared and decomposed into right prisms, each of whose volume is just base * height. The heights are the column entries of the decomposed vector, and the bases are the cofactor determinants.
In essence, the cofactor expansion is shearing the parallelepiped into cuboids, applying Cavalieri's Principle over and over again.
